properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system developing over the Southern Plains States is tracking toward the Maritimes. A taste of the system will give 5 to 10 centimetres of snow before it weakens Thursday afternoon. The snow will redevelop again during Thursday night and fall heavily until late Friday. A total snowfall of 20 to 30 centimetres is expected by Friday. Quickly accumulating snowfall may make travel particularly difficult Friday. Consider adapting your travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T21:17:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T05:18:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1634539411.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Light snow will continue today, possibly mixed with freezing drizzle. Additional light snow will be possible tonight into Friday morning. Total snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 10 cm range are expected for most areas. Given the timing of the snow, the this morning commute as well as the the afternoon or evening commute are likely to be impacted. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely. However, Snowfall warnings are not anticipated at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:48:58-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and freezing rain expected. Locations: central and southern New Brunswick. Time span: this morning to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin in the southwest this morning and spread north across the rest of the province throughout the day. Parts of southern New Brunswick will likely see a changeover to ice pellets and freezing rain tonight, then a change back to snow on Friday night. Additionally, strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. Freezing rain warnings are in effect for parts of the Fundy coast and snowfall warnings are in effect for northern New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:03:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T09:04:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3924664860.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, and possible ice pellets and freezing rain for the end of the week. Total snowfall: near 15 cm, and possibly more. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time span: Thursday evening to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin this evening and continue tonight and Friday. The snow is expected to become mixed with ice pellets on Friday afternoon and possibly with freezing rain on Friday evening, before precipitation changes back to snow later Friday night. At this time, forecast guidance indicates that the area of heaviest snowfall will remain just west of the Islands, but this could change if the track of the system bringing the snow shifts further to the east. Strong northeasterly winds on Friday afternoon and evening, followed by strong northwesterly winds early Saturday morning, will cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off to flurries on Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:05:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T09:06:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3509198525.2020
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Thursday and Friday. A low pressure system developing over the Southern Plains States is tracking toward the Maritimes. Light snow will gradually move over Eastern Quebec on Thursday and intensify beginning Thursday night. A total snowfall amount between 15 and 25 centimetres is expected through Saturday morning. Blowing snow is also expected for areas near the shore of the St. Lawrence beginning Friday through Saturday morning. Travel conditions could be difficult. Consider adapting your travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T21:18:39-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chills are in the minus 45 to minus 50 range in parts of northernmost Manitoba. Wind chills should moderate somewhat this afternoon. However, extreme wind chills are likely to return for Thursday night and into Friday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T02:34:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T10:35:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2133469839.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Locations: central and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Periods of snow will develop by morning on Friday. Snowfall rates will be relatively light during the day on Friday, but will become heavy, at times on, Friday night. Over some areas, the snow may mix with ice pellets later Friday night. Snow will continue into Saturday with strengthening northerly winds resulting in blowing snow. The snow and wind will begin to ease over most areas by late Saturday, but onshore flurries and snow squalls may persist over parts of western Newfoundland into Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:15:44-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow today into Friday. Snow associated with a low pressure system from Texas is expected to continue through the day and may become mixed with ice pellets near the St. Lawrence river this afternoon. The snow will then continue tonight into Friday morning. Additional light snowfall will be possible Friday before the snow finally comes to an end Friday evening. Total snowfall accumulations in the 8 to 12 cm range will be possible by Friday evening. The Thursday morning and Thursday afternoon commutes are likely to be impacted by this snowfall. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely. However, Snowfall warnings are not anticipated at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:49:41-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and freezing rain are expected, followed by large waves, pounding surge and elevated sea water levels. Total snowfall and ice pellets: 10 to 15 cm (late tonight through Friday). Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm (Friday night). Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h (Saturday). Wave heights: 6 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore (Saturday). Locations: Burgeo to Connaigre. Remarks: Snow will begin overnight and change to ice pellets during the day on Friday. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening, and then eventually change to a brief period of rain before ending overnight Friday night. Strong southwesterly winds will develop on Saturday morning and ease Saturday afternoon. Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the southwest, especially near the morning high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:14:01-00:00

properties.Summary:

Wind chills should moderate Thursday afternoon. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow and ice pellets are expected, followed by freezing rain. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: near 15 cm. Locations: northwestern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: Flurries will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning. A transition to ice pellets will then slowly migrate northward over the region Friday morning and afternoon. Extreme northern areas will likely receive near 15 cm of snow before the transition. Further south, snowfall totals are expected to be lower, but will be followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening and eventually to rain later Friday night. A freezing rain warning may be required with subsequent forecasts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:07:54-00:00

Area: Avalon Peninsula North

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected tonight and Friday. Total snowfall: 15 to 35 cm, possibly more. Locations: northern and parts of central New Brunswick. Time span: near noon today to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of light snow will begin near noon today. Current guidance indicates that there will be a break in the snow this evening, then it will re- intensify overnight and become heavy at times throughout the day on Friday. Snow will continue through Friday night and then taper off to flurries Saturday morning. Additionally, strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets and then freezing rain is expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 10 to 15 cm. Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm except 15 to 25 mm along the southern shore. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Locations: Metro St. John's and the eastern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: Snow will begin overnight and then change to ice pellets Friday morning. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain later Friday morning along the southern shore, while further north (including the Metro St. John's area), the ice pellets are expected to be more prolonged before eventually changing to to freezing rain late Friday afternoon. The freezing rain will change to rain near midnight Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:06:36-00:00

Area: St. John's and vicinity

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system developing over the Southern Plains States is tracking toward the Maritimes. A small taste of the system will give about 5 centimetres of snow before it weakens late Thursday. The snow will redevelop again during Thursday night and persist until late Friday. In addition, blowing snow whipped up by strong northeasterly winds will give greatly reduced visibilities especially in areas near the St Lawrence River. A total snowfall of 15 to 25 centimetres is expected by Friday. Quickly accumulating snow and blowing snow could make travel particularly difficult Friday. Consider adapting your travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-06T21:19:52-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds, large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 100 km/h. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: Saturday morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the southwest, especially near the morning high tide on Saturday. In addition, after a short mild spell Friday night, temperatures will fall below freezing again during the day on Saturday. Surfaces may become slippery as residual water freezes. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and freezing precipitation are expected. Total snowfall and ice pellets: 10 to 15 cm. Total freezing precipitation amounts: 2 to 5 mm. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning until overnight Friday night. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin Friday morning, and then change through ice pellets to freezing rain or freezing drizzle Friday night. The freezing precipitation will taper off before morning on Saturday. However, flurries and gusty winds will develop during the day on Saturday with an additional 5 cm of accumulation possible, along with areas of blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and freezing rain expected for the end of the week. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, and possibly more over Prince County. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: this afternoon to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin this afternoon and persist through Thursday night. A changeover to ice pellets and/or freezing rain is expected to occur on Friday, before precipitation changes back to snow on Friday night. Strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may also cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. The snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. It is still uncertain where and when the changeover between snow and mixed precipitation will occur, which will affect the amount and location of the heaviest snowfall and the areas most likely to be threatened by freezing rain. Warnings may be issued with future forecasts as the system approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:59:17-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowmelt and runoff are expected, followed by strong winds and falling temperatures. Maximum gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Remarks: After the freezing rain changes to rain Friday night, temperatures are expected to rise to near plus 8 by early Saturday morning, resulting in melting snow and runoff. Strong southwesterly winds will then develop on Saturday morning and continue into Saturday afternoon. Temperatures will fall back below freezing during the day, causing residual water to re-freeze. Surfaces may become slippery. The winds are expected to ease Saturday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm. Locations: along the Atlantic coast of central Nova Scotia. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin over central Nova Scotia this morning and change through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight, then to rain on Friday morning as temperatures rise above freezing. Along the Atlantic coast, where temperatures are expected to be slightly warmer, precipitation will fall largely as rain tonight. Total rainfall accumulations of 15 to 30 mm are forecast, with the highest amounts expected along the coast. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:02:37-00:00

properties.Summary:

The snow will intensify late tonight and continue into early Saturday morning. Approximately 25 centimetres of snow are expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Thursday and Friday. A low pressure system developing over the Southern Plains States is tracking toward the Maritimes. A small taste of the system will give 5 to 10 centimetres of snow before it weakens Thursday afternoon. The snow will redevelop again during Thursday night and fall heavily until late Friday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 centimetres are expected on Friday. Driving conditions may occasionally be difficult and lead to delay in transportation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system from Texas will bring significant snowfall to the region beginning this morning. The snow will become heavy at times tonight and continue into Friday before tapering of Friday night. Snowfall amounts of 15 cm or more in 12 hours are likely tonight with a total snow fall amounts of 20 to 25 cm possible by Friday night. This morning and afternoon coommutes are likely to be impacted, and possibly the Friday morning commute as well. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold conditions continue this morning, with windchill values in the -45 to -50 range. Conditions will improve later this morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Significant snowfall expected today. Snowfall will return to Allison Pass this morning as a Pacific low pressure system approaches the south coast. The snow is expected to last into this evening giving accumulations of 15 to 20 cm. The snow is forecast to end by late this evening as the low moves to the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula, excluding southernmost coastal areas. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow tonight before changing to ice pellets Friday morning. Over southernmost coastal areas, a quick transition through freezing rain to rain is expected to occur Friday morning. Elsewhere, the transition will take much longer, resulting in a prolonged period of freezing rain. Precipitation is expected to change to rain over all areas by midnight Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:05:27-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A low pressure system from Texas will bring significant snowfall to the region beginning this morning. The snow will become heavy at times tonight and continue into Friday before tapering of Friday night. The snow could also mix at times with ice pellets. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are likely by Friday night. This morning and afternoon coommutes are likely to be impacted, and possibly the Friday morning commute as well. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. Winter storm on Friday. The snow will begin over Central Quebec this morning and will then gradually reach the lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula by tonight. The snow will become heavier overnight and continue throughout Friday. Total snowfall amounts between 15 and 30 centimetres are expected through Saturday morning. In addition, strong northeast winds will gust up to 70 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with the snow will create widespread blowing snow over areas near the shore of the St. Lawrence. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: possibly more than to 20 mm over some inland areas, with lesser amounts over southwestern Nova Scotia and along the coast. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning early this evening in the southwest and continuing into Friday evening over some northern regions. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow this morning and then transition through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight, beginning early this evening in southwestern Nova Scotia and spreading northeastward tonight. In the southwest, freezing rain is expected to quickly change to rain along the coast, but may continue into the overnight hours further inland. The remainder of Nova Scotia will see a prolonged period of freezing rain, which will gradually transition to rain on Friday from south to north as temperatures rise above freezing. Some inland areas may receive total freezing rain accumulations of 20 mm or more from this event. On Friday evening, strong southwesterly winds are expected to develop across much of the province, particularly along the Atlantic coast and the Bay of Fundy. It is possible that wind warnings will be issued with future forecasts. Later on Friday night, winds will diminish and shift to northwesterly as a cold front crossing the province brings snow flurries and a rapid drop to cooler temperatures. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:01:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T09:02:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0789850142.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. An extended period of freezing rain is expected tonight and Friday. Locations: Fundy Coast. Time span: beginning tonight and continuing into Friday evening. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow this morning and then transition through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight. Freezing rain, mixing at times with ice pellets, will continue through the day on Friday, except near Grand Manan Island, where temperatures will remain above zero and rain is expected throughout tonight and Friday. Freezing rain or rain will transition back to flurries on Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T00:54:30-00:00

Area: Saint John and County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, and possibly more in some locations. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia. Time span: early this evening until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin over southwestern Nova Scotia this morning, changing through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain by early this evening. Periods of rain will continue, heavy at times, until ending Friday afternoon or evening. Total rainfall accumulations of 20 to 40 mm are forecast, with the highest amounts expected over Cape Sable Island and vicinity. Freezing rain warnings have also been issued for this event because inland areas are likely to see a more prolonged period of freezing rain, beginning early this evening and continuing until an approaching warm front causes temperatures rise above freezing overnight tonight. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T01:04:33-00:00
